titlePart.supplied: Statement on Birth Control in Puerto Rico

sourceDesc.bibl: Mrs. Sanger Aids Beverley, New York Times, Oct. 9, 1932, p. 9

headNote.p: Sanger sent a telegram sent to President Herbert Hoover, protesting the National Catholic Alumni Federation's opposition to the plans of James R. Beverley, the Governor of Puerto Rico, to provide birth control for the island.

index.level1: National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control

docBody.head: MRS. SANGER AIDS BEVERLEY
Protests to Hoover on Criticism of Birth Control Proposal.

p.q: Margaret Sanger, head of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control, at 17 West Sixteenth Street, made public yesterday a telegram sent to President Hoover protesting against the opposition of the National Catholic Alumni Federation to the advocacy by Governor James R. Beverley of Puerto Rico of birth control for the natives of the island.

docBody.p: “On behalf of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control," I wish to emphatically protest against the deliberate misstatements made by the National Catholic Alumni Federationas reported in The New York Times,” her telegram said. “

Over 200 national and State organizations in medical, religious, social and educational fields have publicly endorsed the principles of birth control and are sponsoring the amendment of anti-birth control laws in this country. It is an arrogant interference on the part of any religious group to attempt to suppress the economic and social facts and to intimidate public officials who dare to present such facts when these are contrary to medieval theology.”
